stem: A 55-year-old client is admitted following a hemorrhagic stroke. Based on the documentation in the Intracranial Pressure & Vital Sign Correlation tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Monitoring for increased intracranial pressure (ICP).
Background: Left-sided hemorrhagic stroke. Current GCS 11.
Assessment: Client reports worsening headache and is now vomiting without nausea (Projectile).
Recommendation: Standard neuro-protective protocol.

tabs.title: Nursing Physical Exam
tabs.content: Cerebral Perfusion Pressure (CPP) is dropping. Pulse pressure is widening (130 mmHg). Client is lethargic and slow to respond to pain.

actionOptions.text: Elevate the head of the bed (HOB) to 30 degrees
Administer IV Mannitol (Osmotic Diuretic) as prescribed
Administer IV fluid boluses to increase blood pressure
Instruct the client to perform the Valsalva maneuver during movements

parameterOptions.text: Pupillary reactivity and Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)
Continuous cardiac and respiratory rate monitoring

rationale.correct: The client shows clear signs of Cushing’s Triad (c2), which is a late sign of increased ICP: Widening pulse pressure (Severe HTN), Bradycardia (HR 48), and Bradypnea (RR 8). The projectile vomiting without nausea is also characteristic. Priority actions are to drain volume through Mannitol (a2) and promote venous drainage via HOB elevation (a1). Mentation/Pupils (p1) and Vitals (p2) are the primary parameters for tracking progression.
clinicalPearls: Cushing’s Triad is the exact opposite of Shock (Shock = Low BP, High HR. ICP = High BP, Low HR).
Mannitol requires a filter needle because it can crystallize at room temperature.
Cerebral Perfusion Pressure (CPP) = MAP - ICP. If BP rises too high or ICP rises too high, the brain starves for oxygen.

questionTrap.trap: Lowering the blood pressure in an ICP patient with antihypertensives.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Avoid aggressive BP lowering! The body is 'clamping down' on the BP to force blood into the high-pressure brain. If you lower the BP, the brain will infarct.

mnemonic.title: Triad vs Shock
mnemonic.expansion: Shock: BP Down, HR Up. ICP: BP Up, HR Down.
